function_call.name: classify_risks_PESTLE
function_call.arguments: {"sorted_risks":[{"name":"Biophilic design could potentially contribute to the spread of contagious diseases through the creation of habitats for animals in urban areas.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Lack of appropriate water management in biophilic design could lead to the proliferation of disease-carrying vectors such as mosquitoes.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Biophilic design may not be effectively implemented in sustainable architecture","category":"Infrastructure risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Disagreement on the interpretation of challenges in sustainable architecture","category":"Infrastructure risks","confidence":"Low"},{"name":"Variable contribution of architecture to different sustainable development goals sdgs","category":"Economic risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Contagious diseases spread in built environments","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Overlaps and repetitions in biophilic design elements may lead to confusion in interpretation and implementation.","category":"Infrastructure risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Diverse nature attributes and their classification in architectural design","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Divergent elements in nature-based architectural design theories","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Psychological experience of nature in architectural design","category":"Social risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Ambiguous terminology around ’experience of space and place’ and its relation to contact with nature","category":"Social risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Overlap and ambiguity in the categorization of nature-related elements in the frameworks","category":"Social risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Requirement for specific arrangements for producing pleasurable experiences in nature-related spaces","category":"Social risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Close contact in congested areas may facilitate the spread of contagious diseases.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Inadequate ventilation and air quality may increase the risk of airborne disease transmission.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of natural elements and outdoor exposure may impact mental health and immune function.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Biophilic design may be misinterpreted or misapplied, leading to ineffective implementation of nature-based elements in architecture.","category":"Infrastructure risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Failure to consider the cultural and ecological context of natural elements in biophilic design may lead to insensitivity or disconnection with the local environment and community.","category":"Social risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Ambiguity in the definition of ’natural spaces’ and ’biophilic design’ may lead to inconsistent interpretation and implementation.","category":"Social risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Lack of clarity in taxonomies of ’nature’ in the frameworks may result in misinterpretation and inappropriate application of biophilic design principles.","category":"Social risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Differences in interpretations and frameworks may lead to conflicting design approaches and criteria for biophilic design in practice.","category":"Infrastructure risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Dependence on ’nature’ for survival leading to potential contamination and spread of contagious diseases.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Negative psychological effects of certain ’nature’ elements , fear of snakes, spiders leading to mental health impacts.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Inadequate understanding of biophilic design principles leading to inefficient integration of ’nature’ in architecture.","category":"Infrastructure risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Contact with natural features vegetation and water can generate a quick and positive psychological reaction, reducing negative emotions and fostering recovery from physiological stress and health problems.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Focus on human contact with natural systems and processes in the built environment could lead to the spread of contagious diseases through exposure to natural elements.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"The theory of biophilia and the instinctive human need for contact with nature may lead to a greater likelihood of exposure to infectious agents present in natural elements.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Contagious diseases transmission in built environment due to close interactions and shared spaces.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of ventilation and natural light in built environment leading to poor indoor air quality and mental health issues.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Use of snowball method to identify publications may result in biased selection of literature, leading to incomplete understanding of biophilic design.","category":"Economic risks","confidence":"Low"},{"name":"Selection of limited literature on the development of relevant concepts may lead to a narrow perspective on the emergence of biophilic design.","category":"Economic risks","confidence":"Low"},{"name":"Limited representation of interdisciplinary knowledge may restrict the applicability of biophilic design to address contagious disease propagation in the built environment.","category":"Economic risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Potential for transmission of contagious diseases through physical contact with natural elements in biophilic design buildings.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Inadequate ventilation and air circulation in biophilic design buildings leading to poor indoor air quality and increased risk of airborne contagions.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of awareness and understanding of biophilic design principles leading to improper implementation and maintenance of natural elements.","category":"Infrastructure risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Lack of contact with nature in the built environment","category":"Social risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Criticism of ’green-washing’ or ’placebo’ strategies related to nature in architecture","category":"Social risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Biophilia leading to close contact with infectious organisms or vectors","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Loss of biodiversity leading to environmental imbalance and disease emergence","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Shift in focus of biophilia theory leading to neglect of human-nature relationship","category":"Social risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Lack of access to gardens, parks, or countryside during covid-19 lockdown","category":"Social risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Concealment of lack of real improvements or effectiveness in ’greening’ of architecture","category":"Political risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Elusive interpretation of the notion of ’nature’ in architectural design","category":"Social risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Climate crises, biodiversity loss, air pollution, and other sustainable challenges","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Limited research on the impact of nature-based design in architecture","category":"Economic risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Significant impact of buildings on human health and well-being","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Use of front porches to link houses and nature","category":"Infrastructure risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Ambiguous definition of ’nature’ in architecture may lead to misunderstandings and debates about its effectiveness.","category":"Social risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Literal greening used as a marketing tool may create false expectations and limited impact on social, economic, and environmental challenges.","category":"Economic risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Inadequate consideration of disease transmission in natural design elements could pose a risk to public health in built environments.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium"}]}
